channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: When I first started at MIT, Peter shared everything with me, copies of his grants, lab budget, much advice, etc. I used to have regular dinners with Peter. I learned to always let Peter choose the wine. If not, he would complain about the wine. :)

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: A new study shows that flowers have evolved over the past three decades to have less sex—possibly in response to the disappearance of bees. It could be a death spiral for some species. Here’s my story. Gift link: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/01/04/science/flower-sex-evolution-bees.html?mwgrp=a-dbar&unlocked_article_code=1.LE0._inN.7uQQgiu7kYGW&smid=url-share

item.title: Enron Hubbard
item.description:
For years, I’ve been Bothered by things like dating apps and social media as superimposing consumer culture into intimacy and the Self. I’ve talked with people about capitalism working its way up the hierarchy of needs, having long since colonized food and shelter and safety, now setting its sights on belonging, connection, and self-actualization.For the most part, people have made me feel like I’m being unnecessarily alarmist and out of touch for having this view. I’ve questioned my sanity and relevance as a result.To hear Klein call this out directly, and speak about it as a profoundly painful experience, has been a vindicating relief. She’s right: it’s the last frontier of privatization, and it should horrify us all.From: @parismarx
https://mastodon.online/@parismarx/111698377449962827

item.title: Proton Mail
item.description: Meta wants you to keep Facebook Link History on, here’s why you shouldn’t:“Meta injects special “keylogging” JavaScript onto the website you’re visiting that allows the company to monitor everything you type and tap on, including passwords.”https://gizmodo.com/meet-link-history-facebook-s-new-way-to-track-the-we-1851134018

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Preprint from friend and colleague Brandon Stell on regionalised population coding in the cerebellum of movement error by complex spikes. Neighbouring regions reciprocally encode both sign and amplitude of the error.https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2024.01.03.574031v1?ct=1/2

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Within the motor framework Vinh and Stell developed (joystick control of lick-port position with variable gain), learning is very rapid, akin to Medina/Yang/Lisberger one-trial learning. This suggests that the cerebellum has (acquired) quite capable heuristic strategies for frequently needed adjustments.2/2

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Amazing discovery, non-stop discrimination and a fascinating example of the importance of not discarding an unexpected result.https://physicsworld.com/a/cecilia-payne-gaposchkin-the-woman-who-found-hydrogen-in-the-stars/Edit: we should learn her name "Cecilia Payne".

item.title: Shauna GM
item.description: "To review: Boeing built a plane that was difficult to fly, then added software that autocorrects these difficulties, but decided that if that software fails, the pilot should save the day by figuring out how to fly the difficult-to-fly plane."They didn't even tell the pilots about the software. The pilot of the first crashed 737 Max spent his final minutes "paging through the pilot manual, trying to determine what was going wrong. This was futile; any mention of MCAS had been removed."
